item.title: Writing is Hard
item.description:
I would love to be a good writer, but I find it very difficult to communicate my thoughts eloquently through text. I often find what I write to be clumsy and unnatural to read, and so I find it useful to edit my written thoughts by reading them out loud and correcting whatever feels strange to say. I read books that aren’t written how someone would speak, though, so perhaps there is a voice exclusive to written form that I need to master.

I want this website to be a place where I can write medium to long form thoughts on topics that I find interesting. Mainly as a way to practice writing, but also because sometimes I might think my ideas are actually worth sharing. Some of these ideas are maths adjacent, mainly relating to how I study mathematics effectively, and I think these will probably be easiest for me to write because it’s what I’m most familiar with.

I know the best way to improve my writing will just be to practice writing more, but I also feel like I don’t want to write bad thoughts either. I think it is probably best to just bite the bullet and just write.

item.title: On Short URLs
item.description:
I went back and forth on how to structure URLs for this website. On reading Derek Sivers’ post Short URLs: why and how, I agreed with his reasons - they look nicer and are easier to type and remember - and so thought it would be good to implement his suggestions.

Domain

I decided to use orsonh.art as a shorter (and more fun) domain name, and I was planning on using single word or abbreviated URLs. I instantly ran into my first problem. Ease of communication.

orsonh.art is easier to type, but harder to communicate. As a comment on Sivers’ original post notes

Love the philosophy of short URLS. The only barrier I’ve found is communicating them verbally

I tried to explain my cool new URL to a handful of people, and it always took longer for them to understand than the simpler orsonhart.com. Another upside to using orsonhart.com is that .com is a universally recognised, and more sensible, top-level domain. A friend of mine said “orsonh.art sounds like your an artist named orsonh”.

I did, however, drop the www.. It’s much nicer.

Post Links

After writing a single post, one of the disadvantages of short URLs mentioned by qntm became apparent, “You do actually have to think of something.”. It is hard (impossible?) to write a meaningful link using very few characters. I like the fact that a slightly longer, although still concise, URL gives you information about the link you are clicking on.

Very few people will remember or type a URL. Most will follow a link posted elsewhere, and so I decided to prioritise

  • Clarity over conciseness.
  • Information over aesthetic.
  • Cleanness over clutter.

item.title: Archiving Hamish and Andy
item.description:
As a digital minimalist, I often want to spend time disconnected. To limit the amount of time I spend using a smartphone, I like to listen to music, audiobooks, and podcasts on my 2009 iPod Classic.

One challenge is that some media is resistant to being accessed offline. This includes my absolute favourite - the Hamish and Andy podcast - which has its entire back catalogue available on Libsyn available with a premium subscription. This post will explain how to download these premium podcasts for archiving or offline listening.

Note: These instructions are designed to work on Windows.

Tools Required

  • A premium Hamish and Andy subscription
  • yt-dlp

Steps

  1. Create a folder for your downloads and put yt-dlp.exe here.
  2. Login to Libsyn and navigate to the page at handa.libsyn.com listing the podcasts you want to download. Scroll to the bottom to load them all.
  3. Open the developer console and use console.log([...document.querySelectorAll("h2 > a.read_more")].map(x => x.href).join("\n")) to get a list of urls. Save these in your folder as urls.txt.
  4. Open Terminal and run the command yt-dlp --cookies-from-browser BROWSER --batch-file urls.txt -o "/YYYY/MM/%(upload_date>%Y-%m-%d)s %(title)s.%(ext)s" --parse-metadata "title:- %(title)s". Make sure to replace BROWSER with the name of your browser e.g. chrome and /YYYY/MM with the appropriate year and month, e.g. /2013/02.

Note: The --parse-metadata flag stops “Hamish & Andy” from duplicating in the filename if the podcast titles incude “Hamish & Andy -”, and can be removed if appropriate.

Let yt-dlp run and all the podcast files should be downloaded to the specified /YYYY/MM folder. A screenshot of the podcasts from February 2013 is below.
